data.text: Cancelled My Bikepacking Trip Out of Fear

Hey everyone, I‚Äôve got kind of a weird question for you today. Long winded background, I apologize. I tried bikepacking for the first time (solo), loaded up, weather looked great spirits were high, and I was about 15 miles from my campsite when suddenly the weather took a turn for the worse. It was pouring rain, whipping wind, with a bad thunderstorm directly overhead. A couple trees came down across the trail I was on, at times gusts almost knocked me over, and despite all my rain gear my shoes and socks became a puddle. I took shelter under a bridge, where the thunderstorm got much worse (I‚Äôm terrified of lightning). My electronics bag also soaked through, because it was out of my dry bag when the downpour started. Between the wet shoes, the wet electronics, the anxiety from the thunder, and a closure of part of the trail due to downed trees, when I got a gap in the weather I ended up bailing and going home by train. Now that I‚Äôm home, I kind of regret that decision. The weather eventually passed, and all the problems that I had could have been easily overcome. But in the moment I was overwhelmed and didn‚Äôt have the resolve to push though. So my question is this: for those who have struggled with this or something similar in the past, how do you get over it? Any advice to follow through and actually finish trips? I know there‚Äôs nothing wrong with bailing, and it should always be considered when safety is an issue, but what about when discomfort is the biggest risk? Thanks in advance.

data.text: Lots of empathy for you Tyler. I recently bailed on a solo bikepack trip myself.I started my ride the day after leaving my job, and for the first day and a half of a three day ride, I was in a really, really negative headspace. A place I had never been before. I was miserable the whole time, despite the fact that the ride was gorgeous, and physically I felt great. But mentally, I was having a terrible time for some strange reason, and just wanted it to be over. Ultimately, I decided to pull the plug on the ride about 60% of the way through. I didn't see my mental state changing. I decided to call it because I ride bikes to have fun. That's my goal. I have nothing to prove to anyone, and I know that physically I could have finished the ride. I regret nothing. Sure, it was a bummer and it was a sad experience, but I am glad I called it. When I was deciding whether to call it or keep riding, I got so hung up on the idea of "what's the right decision??", when in reality there is no right or wrong decision! It simply doesn't fucking matter. We act like people give a shit about what we do. They don't. Only we do, and we gotta do what makes us happy. Your route, and my route, will still be there in the future, and I definitely plan to redo my trip in the next year.

It was just supposed to be a 2 night/2 1/2 day bikepacking trip, but we encountered multiple downed trees, and after bushwhacking for almost 3 hours, and only making it a few miles, we decided to turn around. Could we have continued? Probably. Was it fun? Not really. And that is the thing. Granted, our definition of fun as bikepackers is a little different from the general population, but in the end, this is supposed to be fun. If it‚Äôs not fun, then why do it? Yes, we can do hard things, and in a certain frame of mind, we find fun in those hard things, but sometimes, it‚Äôs okay to just say this isn‚Äôt fun, so I‚Äôm bailing. data.text: Anxiety is probably more common than many like to admit. I understand your concerns. I have two little mantras that I use to push me through: If afraid to go, go anyway. Go with fear. If one person can do it, so can another. The second one informs the first. I am astounded everyday when I read what others have done bike packing. Sub-zero weather, bears, war zones... I am pretty sure that most had some anxiety around the first step of that journey. They started anyway. Look at all that bike packers (and humanity) have accomplished. It is highly probable that you will survive your adventure. If not, you will go down in legend. Prepare the best you can. Trust that you will make it. Long may you ride!

data.text: No worries thats how we learn. Experience is a better teacher than any advice someone can tell you offhand. Having said that, I've made sure every one of my bikepacking bags are waterproof, and I pack them so worst-case scenarios can be dealt with quickly. Raincoat and first aid is at the top of any bag they live in. Electronics can be convenient to get but protected from water when not in use. Knowing that if it starts dumping rain I don't need to worry about anything except getting to safety makes me feel better than having to think through all the vulnerable equipment in a moment of panic.
